utterances: All of the children are going home.
Even the under-aged, pregnant mothers and the under-aged pregnant teens and the under-aged mothers are all going home.
That's not to say they're necessarily going to stay home.

I think that what's going to happen now is child protective services will proceed as it usually does, bringing individual charges in individual cases and so it's not guaranteed that just because these temporary orders were vacated that new orders won't be entered in.
And all of the parents also had to agree to attend parenting classes.
Right, I mean that's standard, that's standard operating procedure.
I mean given the group's feelings about the state, I just wonder how successful parenting classes might be.
Not that the mothers and fathers won't attend, not that they won't be respectful, but frankly they view outsiders as gentiles, as Babylonians.
I expect them to be very distrustful of what they're going to be taught.
I'm not sure what the state of Texas hopes to achieve with that order.
And I understand that yesterday an elder from the FLDS Church said that in the future the Church would not condone unions involving minors.
Right and that's a - I think that's a change so that's an announcement that will probably be welcomed by the state.
FLDS, although it was not unheard of, the practice of marrying under-aged teens to older men really got started with Warren Jeffs' father, Rulon Jeffs in Ernest.
Not that it never happened before, yes it did.

But Rulon Jeffs, and then Warren Jeffs kind of took that practice up a notch and I don't think many members of the FLDS will feel like this is a blow against them if they go back to having plural marriages between older, young women and older men.
And the - they said that without acknowledging that such unions had happened in the past or at least not openly acknowledging.
Well he did say let's not blame the many for the mistakes of a few which I would say is a tacit acknowledgment of the - mistakes were made as you might say.
Will child protective services still have access to see these children to make sure they are OK?
Yes, they have access from 8:00 AM to 8:00 PM.
There's no limit on the access and I expect child protective services are going to be very involved back at the ranch.
One lawyer for one young woman, the daughter of Warren Jeffs asks that orders be entered for her protection.
There were hints that she might have been sexually abused so this is - I mean we are far.
All of the children are going back today.
This is - we are still very much in the middle of this process.
Wade Goodwyn, thanks very much, appreciate it.
It's my pleasure.
NPR's Wade Goodwyn covering the FLDS case, and he joined us by phone outside the Yearning for Zion Ranch in El Dorado, Texas.
And just again, a reminder, the FLDS has no connection with the main stream Mormon Church.
Joining us now is Jackie Carter.

She's the Executive Director of the High Sky Children's Ranch in Midland, Texas which housed 15 girls from the FLDS compound in El Dorado and she joins us now by cell phone from Midland, Texas and it's good of you to be with us today.
Thank you.
And have the girls that you were housing, have they been released back to their parents?
Well we tried to honor their culture and we bought sewing machines and they all made their clothing, made dresses.
We provided a gardening area for them, and they were very good at baking and cooking I have to say.
So they were very skilled and very knowledgeable.
And were they in school, were they getting classes of any sort?
Actually, we had the Midland Public School come and do an assessment, and they were going to go to summer school if the plan if the plan had been for them to remain.
But all of them were very smart and could read and had great many skills.
And when you talked to them about the world around them did they seem aware of what was going on?
To some extent.
Could you elaborate a little, if you would?
Well, really they did not want to talk about the world as such.
They were mostly concerned with their situation, and we understood that.
That was a very difficult situation for them to be removed from their families, and that was their main concern for the time that they were with us.
Though they did relax and have some fun and develop some relationships.
And when you said you honored their culture.
Did they watch television, look at a computer, anything like that?
No, they do not watch television.
We had everything removed from the home that they were not interested in.
They sang and listened to sermons, did their daily routine.
They did play outside, we have a gymnasium and they played ball, and played in the water.
But they did not watch TV or play computer games.
And when you said they were reading - the Bible, the newspaper, what?
Well, no, actually they had some of their materials that they read, and listened to on tape.
Oh, listened to on tapes.
So they had tape recorders or...
Actually, iPods.
IPods.
OK, well there's...
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, there's a bit of the modern world that might have come have come to some of us as a surprise.
Well, they are very knowledgeable of the modern world, and technically, so.
So they know of what computers are and that sort of thing, they just...
Oh, yes.
Probably don't have Face Book pages.
Yes.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I understand their departure must have been a sad one for you, in some ways.
It was for us.
I think they were very happy to go home, but yet they gave us hugs.
They wanted their picture taken with us, they said they would come and see us.
Their parents were very polite and nice, and I was very sad to see they go and it's a hard day.
It's a hard day, and I expect that by tomorrow probably all of them will be gone.
Yes.
By this afternoon they will all be gone.
By this afternoon, so this process is still continuing.
Were the parents resentful of the process at all when they have to provide ID and finger prints and that sort of thing?
No, they were actually very polite, very kind and nice.
Thanked my staff and the CPS workers for their time and their help, very pleasant.
And the kids were thrilled to be back with their parents?
Oh, yes.
They were very excited.
Mostly mothers showed up, and they were thrilled to see their mothers.
Of course, parents have been visiting every day since the girls were placed.
So they have maintained contact with their families.
Yes.
Well, Jackie Carter thanks very much for your time today, we appreciate it.
Thank you.
Jackie Carter, Executive Director of the High Sky Children's Ranch at Midland, Texas, where they housed 15 girls from the FLDS Compound in El Dorado.
She joined us by phone today, from Midland, Texas.

We're talking about the fallout from the dramatic show-down between Texas Child Protective Services and the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, for the state, for the religious group and especially for the kids.
If you'd like to join us 800-989-8255, email us talk@npr.org.
I'm Neal Conan stay with us, it's the Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
